book.title: The Genealogy of Jesus Christ
book.note: Although the Greek text reads "Aram," many English versions substitute the Old Testament form of the name, "Ram" (cf. 1 Chr 2:9; Ruth 4:19), here and in the following verse
Greek "Asaph," alternately spelled "Asa" in many English versions here and in the following verse (cf. 1 Chr 3:10)
Greek "Josaphat"; alternately spelled "Jehoshaphat" in many English versions
The earliest and best Greek manuscripts read "Amos," but many English versions use the Old Testament form of the name here, "Amon" (cf. 2 Kgs 21:18)
Greek "Salathiel," but many English versions use the Old Testament form of the name here, "Shealtiel" (cf. Ezra 3:2)
book.title: The Birth of Jesus Christ
book.note: The Greek relative pronoun is feminine gender and thus refers only to Mary, not Joseph
An allusion to Isa 8:8,10 in the Greek OT (LXX)
book.title: Wise Men Visit Jesus
book.note: Or, "when it rose"; traditionally rendered "in the east" by many English versions
Or, "when it rose"; traditionally rendered "in the east" by many English versions
book.title: Joseph, Mary, and Jesus Escape to Egypt
Herod Has Innocent Children Murdered
Joseph, Mary, and Jesus Return to Nazareth
book.note: Lit. "that"; the conjunction could be understood (1) to introduce a direct quotation, serving a function similar to modern English quotation marks, and thus not translated; or (2) to introduce an indirect quotation, in which case it could be translated "that he would be called a Nazarene"
book.title: John the Baptist Begins His Ministry
The Baptism of Jesus
book.note: The words "there was" are not in the Greek text, but are supplied to make a complete sentence in English

book.note: Or "nations"; the same Greek word can be translated "nations" or "Gentiles" depending on the context

book.note: Perhaps with the idea of obstinate, godless foolishness; some take the word to be a Greek transliteration of the Hebrew word for "rebel" (Deut 21:18, 20)
Lit. "be making friends quickly with your accuser"

book.note: A Roman mile was originally a thousand paces, but was later fixed at eight stades (1,478.5 meters)

book.note: Or "evil"; most later Greek manuscripts add the phrase "for yours is the kingdom and the power and the glory forever, amen"
book.title: The Sermon on the Mount: Treasure in Heaven
book.note: Traditionally "rust," but more likely in this context along with "moth" the term refers to "eating" by other types of insects or vermin

book.note: Traditionally transliterated from the Greek as "mammon"
Some manuscripts add "or what you will drink"; other later manuscripts add "and what you will drink"
Some manuscripts have "the kingdom of God and his righteousness"
Lit. "sufficient for the day its trouble"

A Leper Cleansed
A Centurion's Slave Healed
book.note: Traditionally "servant"; the Greek term here is one often used of a slave who was regarded with some degree of affection, possibly a personal servant (the parallel passage in Luke 7:7 uses the more common term for slave)
book.title: Many at Capernaum Are Healed
book.note: Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation (see the parallel in Luke 7:8).

book.note: That is, the other side of the Sea of Galilee

book.note: That is, the other side of the Sea of Galilee
Many manuscripts read "Gergesenes"; others read "Gerasenes" (see Luke 8:26)
Lit. "what to us and to you"
That is, before the appointed time of judgment

Lit. "the sons of the bridal chamber"
book.title: A Woman Healed and a Daughter Raised

book.note: Lit. "never has it been seen thus"
book.title: The Twelve Commissioned and Sent Out
book.note: Lit. "the Cananean," but according to BDAG 507 s.v., this term has no relation at all to the geographical terms for Cana or Canaan, but is derived from the Aramaic term for "enthusiast, zealot" (see Luke 6:15; Acts 1:13)
book.title: Persecution of Disciples Predicted
book.note: A repetition of "that" is supplied in English; the single Greek term is understood to modify both "house" and "town"
book.title: Fear God Rather Than People
book.note: Lit., "an assarion," a Roman coin worth about 1/16 of a denarius

book.note: Some manuscripts have "But what did you go out to see? A prophet?"

book.note: Lit. "fruit," describing here the grain harvested from the healthy plants; in contemporary English this would more naturally be expressed by terms like "grain" or "crop"

book.note: A weed that looks similar to wheat but has poisonous seeds

book.note: Most later Greek manuscripts add v. 21, "But this kind does not go out except by prayer and fasting."
Or possibly "of people," in a generic sense, although the reference here may be to the specific group responsible for Jesus' arrest, where it is unlikely women were present
This refers to the half-shekel annual tax paid by Jewish males to support the temple; over time the name of the coin commonly used to pay the tax came to be used for the tax itself

The Prayer in Gethsemane
book.note: Lit. "for their eyes were weighed down"
book.title: The Betrayal and Arrest of Jesus
book.note: The meaning of this phrase is disputed: (1) some take it as a declarative (as in the translation); (2) others understand it as some form of a question, often with supplied words: (a) "Friend, are you misusing the kiss for that purpose for which you are here?" (b) "Friend, in connection with that for which you have appeared do you kiss me?" (c) "Friend, are you here for this purpose?" (d) "Friend, what are you here for?"; this last option, though often suggested, is doubtful because of lack of evidence for the relative pronoun used as an interrogative in direct questions
book.title: Jesus Before the Sanhedrin

book.note: An indirect way of referring to God

book.note: A quotation from various passages in Jeremiah including 18:2-6; 19:1-13; 32:6-15; see also Zech 11:12-13
book.title: Pilate Releases Barabbas
book.note: Although many manuscripts omit "Jesus" here, it is so hard to explain why a scribe would have added it that the reading is probably original
"Barabbas" means "son of the father" in Aramaic
Lit. "nothing to you and to that righteous man"
